For anybody reading this who isn't sure of the connection between his geometric intuition of linear transformations and the formal/textbook definition of linear transformations it is this. 3B1B says that linear transformations are transformations in which the gridlines are kept parallel and evenly spaced (and kept as lines). This is the same notion as maintaining the scalar multiplication and vector addition properties in the definition of linear transformations i.e if x and y are vectors and c a scalar then T(cx) = cT(x) and T(x+y) = T(x)+T(y). Combining these rules we get T(some linear combo of x and y) = some linear combo of T(x) and T(y).

So that's the same concept as with the basis vectors. A vector that is some particular linear combo of the basis vectors has to, after the transformation, still remain that same particular combination of the transformed basis vectors.

These videos are brilliant! However, I must confess that having seen explanations such as yours, along with a few other math pursuits of mine over the past year, has made me somewhat provoked about the way math is generally taught in the US. I'm 52 and currently have time to pursue some interests of mine for which I previously didn't have time. When I was young, I had a love/hate relationship with math. I was perplexed and annoyed with myself that I could often solve complicated problems (like in calculus, for example), but had so much trouble with more mundane ones (like logs). Well, I've come to the realization that when I asked many teachers if they could explain how they solved certain problems, they answered merely by reiterating algorithms and mnemonics. Matrices have made this quite vivid. Though usually superb, Khan Academy left me very confused. I spent several dozen (yes!) frustrating hours trying to square matrix multiplication (the algorithm, that is) with linear transformations, and it wasn't until I finally used that method side-by-side with what you have so brilliantly taught here that I realized the mnemonic algorithm (for solving what x and y vectors become when i and j are transformed) of "line/row" is actually devoid of intuitive content. It's much like telling someone that the way to spell "math" is to "place an h on the right, an ma on the left, and insert a t between the two." Sure, it comes out right at the end, but is contrived and doesn't help in understanding what is being spelled, or why - if that analogy makes any sense. I have had several other experiences - while relearning math I never fully understood - that have led me to believe that the reason I never fully understood some concepts is because they were never actually explained. Instead, in both high school and college, we were taught merely algorithms to churn out correct answers. I've had conversations with others from the US and Canada who have expressed the same sentiment. Interestingly, on several occasions, Russians have expressed that their learning experience with math was quite different. Whatever the case, I find it ironic that it took not being in school to properly learn (and understand) a lot of math. Sorry to ramble for so long; I was interested to see if any others have had the same experience. I also want to reiterate my thanks for these lessons. You're a brilliant teacher.

Linear transformations are functions, and in the case of 2D the matrix representation of a linear transformation is the codomain of a function of the the domain vector system onto the codomain vector system, with the domain of the function being an ordered pair of the basis vectors i hat and j hat.

As a general rule can it be said that a linear transformation is a codomain in the form of any ordered n-tuple (T) of ordered n-tuples (<x,y,z..>coordinates, Cn) in which the arity of any Cn is the same as arity of T, and the same as the arity of the domain coordinate tuples (<x,y,z...>), such that each Cn can be described as a linear combination of the basis vectors of the domain and thus the span of the domain coordinate system will include each Cn of T?

In the spirit of your style of explanation, which I think is very nice overall, you could a) remove some of the grid lines for units less than 1 (most students in the US aren't used to seeing these and it can be disorienting to look at a transformed grid with them); and b) explain where the transformations of i-hat and j-hat come from in that example. You do a good job of this overall, but one thing I've learned from teaching is that it really can't hurt, every time you use an example with arbitrary numbers, to remind students that that specific part of the problem is arbitrary and could change. Granted, I teach a course without much in the way of math prerequisites, but every time that I forget to mention this, someone misunderstands the numbers that I randomly pick as examples as being somehow integral to the problem. And, conversely, every time I refer to pi or e without mentioning that they are fixed constants and not variable quantities that are also represented by letters, such as x or sigma, people think they're just variables.

+ We can describe each of the infinitely many points in a 2D space just by two numbers forming a 2D vector
+ A 2D vector describes how much to go into the direction of the 2 unit vectors forming the coordinate frame
+ Thus, to describe the transformation of a 2D space (infinitely many points), we just need to transform the coordinate frame!

Good times, this video gave me memories ☺️

For those that know Maxwell's Equations of Classical Electrodynamics, I'm doing a computational analysis of two interacting point charges, so I'm gonna use Dirac functions to capture the location of the relevant charges (i.e. using a scalar field to define the two charges). This allows me to use a nonlinear transformation matrix to describe the motion of the Dirac functions, which is nice because the current density function (J) equals said scalar field times the local velocity, meaning the rate at which the transformation moves the points on the field can be used to derive the J!

When he told me to think about it, I thought about it for a while, and determined the following! A linear transformation will flip the basis vectors/space (such that i hat will now be "to the left of" j hat) iff the 2nd coordinate of i hat and the 1st one of j hat (that left-right bottom-top diagonal) are both strictly greater than at least one of the other 2 remaining coordinates (the right-left-top-bottom diagonal). You can even define a flip that way in case you get confused by the visual. Try it out with all the examples, and use it to explain to yourself why the shear example didn't result in a flip: it's because the 2nd coordinate of i hat ofc can't overtake the 1st one, since neither change and it was 0 (which is < 1) to begin with, and then it can't overtake the 2nd coordinate of j hat either so long as j hat stays within the positive (1st) quadrant, since that coordinate will just keep growing; and even if it goes to 0, it won't be strictly less than i-hat's 2nd coordinate until it goes into the 4th quadrant, at which point the basis vectors will flip in this example as long as the 1st coordinate of j hat stays positive (specifically, in this example, stays greater than the 2nd). Anyway, it's easier to just take the rule and apply it to the visuals yourself! And thinking about things yourself in this way instead of trying to interpret a wall of text is a much better way of internalizing these things. Anyway, this video series is the greatest thing ever!

The professor was looking at the linear transformation in an active way. Actually, we can look at the linear transformation from another different angle too, a passive way. For example, let's stop at 4:27 and look at the screenshot there. There are two different grid systems here: the regular square grid ---Let me call it Bob's grid; another grid system is the tilted larger grid ---Let me call it Rachel's grid. That yellow vector's coordinates are (5, 2)b and (-1, 2)r in Bob's grid system and Rachel's grid system respectively. Please note: it is the same vector. It has different coordinates with regards to two different reference systems. How do we convert from (-1, 2)r to (5, 2)b? By the linear transformation. The basis vectors in Rachel's grid are: (1, 0)r=(1, -2)b (0, 1)r=(3, 0)b So matrix A=(1 3, -2 0) det(A)=6. The matrix A converts (-1, 2)r to (5, 2)b. The inverse of A is: 1/6(0 -3, 2 1), which converts (5, 2)b to (-1, 2)r. In conclusion, the linear transformation is converting the vector's coordinates from one grid system to another. The vector itself doesn't move or change at all. One analogy is: I walked 1 mile this morning, or 1.6 kilometer. The distance I walked this morning is fixed. The number(1.0 or 1.6) changes due to different unit system.

I'd like an opinion on the following:
Consider the line passing through the vectors x,y. Let z be any point on the line through x and y. Then z=(1-t)x+ty for some real t. So Tz=(1-t)Tx+tTy which means z is sent upon the line through the images of x and y. Since z is arbitrary, any point on the line through x and y will be sent to the line through Tx and Ty. Thus lines are preserved.
What's interesting is that Tz divides the segment [Tx,Ty] in the same ratio as z divides [x,y]. What's the significance of this?

Great series.  One point though - transformations are indeed beautiful, but the "feeling of squishing and morphing space itself" is, in my humble opinion, (and not mine only), is far from correct.  Changing the grid does nothing to space itself.  Thus "curved space" is a misnomer - it's the grid that curves, not space itself.   "Curved space" describes a mathematical construct that supposedly explains modern cosmology.  But standard cosmology, SBBC, has many, many problems including this one.

I think it would be awesome to see a video where you showed the effects of important linear operators such as adjoints, self-adjoint, normal, unitary, and positive ones.

For example, showing that self-adjoint and normal operators will have orthonormal eigenbases in real and complex vector spaces, respectively. So that would mean that the the transformation will keep grid lines orthogonal while rotating and/or expanding/contracting. Exploring this further (ie other operators) could yield great insight.

Other ideas that might be interesting to visualize are decompositions -- such as LU decomposition and of course singular value!

Lastly, it would be hugely informative to see a visualization of solving a system by converting to reduced row echelon form. After all, the process itself is just a series of linear transformations (http://math.mit.edu/~cyxu/700gauss.pdf).

Thanks a lot for these linear algebra videos. I'm watching and greatly enjoying. I'm like a lot of people who wished teachers spent more time with "why" before going into "how". These videos are excellent help with that.

I have to say, though, that I got badly wrapped around the axle by the example starting at 4:10. How did we get to be talking about [3,0] and [5,2] all of a sudden when just a second ago we were talking about [-1,2]? What are Transformed i-hat and Transformed j-hat? There had to be some dark matter in the explanation that I wasn't seeing.

After playing the video multiple times, I finally got it. It's the sentence, "If we play some transformation..." It whizzed by when it was the key point. The transformation in question (the dark matter) was shown visually but not explained in any other way (say, a clockwise rotation), and Transformed i-hat and Transformed j-hat are the names of where the i-hat and j-hat vectors land after the transformation. My experience of it was to be confused, and all the grid lines going everywhere made things less clear rather than more.

Maybe just a couple more sentences to ground the example would be helpful. It's the most important part of the video. Once I figured out what the moving parts in the example were, I found it useful and the rest of the lecture followed nicely from it.

Thanks again. I'm now a subscriber to your channel and looking forward to seeing more.

I think one of the most confusing things (or at least for me) is what coordinates really mean. They just mean how much one moves depending what your basis vectors are. In this case the final expression where people just memorize the formula for matrix multiplication actually means something. It means the coordinates of the transformed vector T(v) in the original coordinate system, since T(v) = aT(i) + b T(j) is the new coordinate system, one could have still represented T(v) with [a, b] in the new coordinate system, T(i), T(j) (hopefully T(i) and T(j) are independent and span a real space...). Since you say in your video on e^(pi*i) that *i corresponds to a rotation by 90 degrees, would then i be the equivalent of a rotation matrix?
i* = |0 -1|
|1 0|
But then +i which corresponds to sliding of the complex plane, would lead to a weird matrix with an operation in one of its slots instead of a number:
i+ = |1 0 |
|0 y+1|

Another thing I noticed was that if you play the rotation game with complex numbers, say <1, i>, and multiply it by i, you get <i, -1> which would be "meaningless" unless you remembered that it could also be represented as -1 + i which would be plotted as if it was <-1, i> in which case it would be like being allowed to just swap the place of x and y axis after each rotation. Another possibility would be to think of it as a 4 dimensional space, where <i, -1> would not be equivalent to <-1, i>.

It feels like the fact that we get to swap the places of x and y in a "complex vector" is a clue to something much bigger!

Linear algebra entered my life as I started to try and learn about machine learning. A basic operation in artificial neural networks (large statistical models used for classification, prediction, and many other cool things) is s(W*x+b), where W is a matrix, x a vector (representing a particular data point), b a vector, and s the sigmoid function (a nonlinearity). You can imagine each data point x as part of a cloud of points which we want to tease apart according to some rule. I imagine the cloud of points being stretched, rotated, and skewed by W, though still remaining jumbled, then b shifting the transformed points. Finally the visual perspective also makes clear why adding a nonlinearity, which can bend and warp space, can be very helpful in separating points that would otherwise remain entangled.

I like to think about the transformation matrix simply as a map of inputs to outputs. In my head, I put the input vector above the transformation matrix, and visualize it as a table. I multiply the values in the columns of the transformation matrix by the respective input vector component and then sum across the rows.

You can also think of each number in the transformation matrix as a description of how the initial components affect the output components. for a 2x2 matrix, the upper left number shows how the initial x coordinate influences the output x coordinate. The upper right describes how the initial y coordinate influences the output x coordinate. Same goes for the bottom row. The lower left number describes how the initial x influences the final y, and the lower right describes how the initial y influences the final y. This is why I like to think of this as a table, with inputs on top and the outputs at the side.

Furthermore, coming up with the 2D rotation matrix is quite easy once we remember that the columns tell us where the basis vectors get sent. The vector (1,0) gets rotated to (cos(θ),sin(θ)) and the vector (0,1) gets rotated to (-sin(θ),cos(θ)). Just load those new vectors into the columns of a matrix and that's it.
